The International Crisis Group said today - there was a complaint that this cease-fire is, quote, ""simply playing into the hands of the government of Sudan."" Did you worry about the prospect that you were just getting played for time in an agreement that the government really has no intention of sticking to?
Well, you know, there have been about two cease-fires, three cease-fires.
And it takes, basically, two to tango.
You can't just say the government has to observe it.
It's the government and the rebels.

And what I think is important is that we'd set forth a structure that leads to a March 15th - this was also in our statement - a March 15th peace agreement that the government and the three rebel groups observe.
Now, two of the three rebel groups have said they're going to not violate the cease-fire.
The government says they won't, either.
One of the rebel groups is objecting.
So until we get all parties involved, it's not going to be a better situation.
But I do think that while not all of the cease-fire has been perfect, there has been a lessening of violence.
And I do believe that international pressure has gotten to Bashir.
But, you know, there's groups like that and others that would rather sit in their armchairs and just say my God, this is terrible.
But we've got to fix things.
You've got to fix things.
You've got to go in there and meet with the rebels and pressure them and get engaged.
You know, there are a lot of armchair quarterbacks.
Admittedly, this is not a perfect cease-fire.
But I think for the first time, there's hope on all sides.
And you've got the U.N.
there, the African Union fighting hard.
You've got the Save Darfur people.
They're increasing their pressure, and that's good.
You've got the international community, the Congress having hearings.
So I think we had a valuable service.
One of the things I know you'd hoped to do - you mentioned the African Union there, about a few thousand troops there.

And I know that you spoke with their commander, and he's told you as he's told everybody else who asks, he doesn't have enough men to begin to enforce, and in fact, he doesn't even have the mandate to really enforce peace efforts in that part of Darfur.
One of your goals was to convince President Bashir to allow a United Nations force with greater authority into the area, and he refused to do that.
He did, but we moved them forward a little bit.
Here's how.
He had previously said no U.N.
troops.
But I think through the pressure of Andrew Natsios, the administration and others, he did open the door a little bit and said he'd be willing to allow U.N.
troops with blue helmets as long as they were logistics, administrative.
Now that's a start.
And I think he's going to realize that we're looking at about 20,000 troops that are going to be needed for peacekeeping.
There are not going to be enough African Union troops because they're going to be in Somalia.
There are other parts of Africa.
They're not that well trained, poorly equipped.
I think he's going to realize they have a real, enforceable peace - which he is going to need just for his own domestic reasons and survival - that he will have a U.N.
peacekeeping presence.
Now, the secretary-general of the U.N., Ban Ki-moon, is going to be in Africa in late January, and he's going to meet with Bashir.
So we keep moving him forward.
We keep pushing.
And because of this continued pressure, Bashir is opening the door a little bit.
Admittedly, he is resisting, but if we can push him, keep pressure on - the worst thing we can do is give up and say this is not going to happen.
This is hopeless.
You've got to have sustained international pressure.
Get China involved.
It's a big client of Sudan's oil.
And Andrew Natsios was out in China getting the Chinese more engaged.
So this advances step by step.
And I think eventually, he's going to recognize that he needs those U.N.
troops.
